Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary below:

Executive Summary

The Risk Management Program includes an Executive Summary as required by Section 2745.3 of Title 19, California Code of Regulations and the Federal RMP Guidance. The Executive Summary provides a discussion of the various Risk Management Program elements as follows:

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 2. Stationary Source Activities 3. Regulated Substances Handled 4. Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios 5. Prevention Program 6. Five-Year Accident History 7. Emergency Response Program 8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety 9. Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

TVMWD has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2735-2785).  TVMWD is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. The facility's staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using anhydrous ammonia and chlorine for water treatment.

TVMWD has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Chlorination and Ammoniation Systems.  TVMWD's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 


2. Stationary Source Activities

The Plant is located at 1021 E. Miramar Avenue, Claremont, CA 91711.

The TVMWD Miramar Water Treatment Plant is located at 1021 Miramar Avenue, Claremont, CA 91711.  The regulated substances managed at the site are anhydrous ammonia and chlorine.

The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia and chlorine are 4,400 lbs and 36,000 lbs, respectively.  Anhydrous ammonia and chlorine are both vacuum regulated and injected for treatment of water.


3. Offsite Consequence Analysis Results Summary

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Per EPA and CalARP Regulations, worst-case release scenarios have been defined and modeled for anhydrous ammonia and chlorine.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: Alternative release scenarios were modeled for anhydrous ammonia and chlorine.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.


4. Risk Considerations

The storage and use of anhydrous ammonia and chlorine have inherent potential risks and the worst-case release scenarios result in consequences that can potentially reach the community.  TVMWD has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  

In addition to the safety practices of TVMWD personnel to extinguish the credibility of these worst-case scenarios, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an anhydrous ammonia or chlorine release:

¿	Safety showers
¿	Respiratory equipment
¿	Gas detection for anhydrous ammonia and chlorine
¿	Diffusion

Tank for the anhydrous ammonia
¿	Scrubber for the Chlorination System

The history of the TVMWD Water Treatment Plant (i.e., no RMP applicable anhydrous ammonia/chlorine releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Chlorination and Ammoniation Systems.


5. Accidental Release Prevention Program

As part of the implementation of the CalARP/EPA RMP Program for the Chlorination System and the CalARP Program 2 for the Ammoniation System, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by TVMWD to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia and chlorine for water treatment.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 4,400 lbs.  Therefore, the regulated substance is under the 10,000 lbs threshold for both the EPA RMP and the Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantities.  The maximum anhydrous ammonia inventory is over the 500 lbs state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 2.

The facility maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 36,000 lbs.  Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 2,500 lbs threshold for EPA RMP, the 1,500 lbs threshold for Cal/OSHA PSM and the 100 lbs state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  As a result, the chlorine covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

Although the amount of anhydrous ammonia is below the Federal Threshold, the chlorine and anhydrous ammonia are both managed as Program 3 substances.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

¿	Process Safety Information
¿	Process Hazard Analysis
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Training
¿	Mechanical Integrity
¿	Manag

ement of Change
¿	Pre-Startup Safety Review
¿	Compliance Audits
¿	Incident Investigation
¿	Employee Participation
¿	Hot Work Permit
¿	Contractors
In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Emergency Response Plan.  See 4.7 (Emergency Response Program) below.


6. Five-Year Accident History

There have been no CalARP applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia and/or chlorine or accidents from a release of the covered process resulting in death, injuries, or significant property damage at TVMWD in the past five years.

7. Emergency Response Program

TVMWD has implemented an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency.  This plan includes:

¿	Emergency Alarm Procedures
¿	Evacuation Procedures
¿	Safety and Health Considerations
¿	Notification Procedure

The most recent review of the facility's Emergency Response Plan occurred on May 1, 2018.  The Emergency Response Plan in place meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 §3220.

9. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the July 10, 2019 PHA Report.

10. Flammables: Worst Case

The use of flammable materials at TVMWD is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

11. Flammables: Alternative Release

The use of flammable materials at TVMWD is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
